lines.text: Environmental Techinology Leners. Vol. 10. pp. 013-626
Publicatioes Divisioe Sciper Ltd., 1969
AIR QUALITY IN PASSENGER CABINS OF DC-9 AND MD-80
AIRCRAFT
Torbjorn Malmfors*", Deniel Thorburs' and Aree Westlin"
'Maimnfors Coasultiog AB, Kammakargatan 48, S-111 60 Stockhoim. Sweden
Department of Statistics, University of Stockhoim, S-106 91 Stockhoim, Sweden
"Igeidammsgatan 14, S-112 49 Stockholm, Sweden
(Received 15 Mey 1989; in final form 7 June 1989)
ABSTRACT
The air quality in the passenger cabins of Dc-9 and MD-so aireraft has been.
studied on 48 representative flights. A portable air sampling case was used. No
observations of health effects were made. The average levels of the components.
related to envirormental tobacco smoke, were for respirable suspended particles
60, 250, 160 and 220 μg/m3; for nicotine 5, 41, 21 and 32 μg/m3; and for carbcn
monoxide 0.6, 1.1, 0.8 and 1.1 ppm in Business Non-Smoking, Business Smoking.
Tourist Non-Smoking and Tourist Smoking sections respeetively. The levels of
carbon dioxide and relative humidity were about 13oo ppm and 2s percent in all
sections respectively.
INTROOUCTION
Very few studies of air quality in aireraft passenger cabins have been performed
due to the technical problens involved. The development of portable air sampling
units has made it possible to do studies under normal operating conditions. Pre-
vious studies have dealt mainly with the impact of envirormental tobacco smoke
(Ers), with cnly limited attention to humidity, temperature, ozone and chemicals
not directiy related to ETs, such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides. They were
constituents of Ers fail to support claims that exposure levels in aircraft affect
reviewed and surmmarized by Holcomb 1988 (1). He concludes that measurements of the
adversely the health of non-snoking passengers or crew and that the available
scientific evidence does not support the prohibition of smoking on comercial air-
craft. Other factors of importance for cabin air quality have also been studied
(2,3, 4, 5). The results of those studies show that aircraft cabin air quality is
generally similar to indoor air quality. except for partieularly low relative
humidity, low air pressure and low oxygen partial pressure.
The present study sought to obtain reliable data on air quality on one series of
aircraft by analyzing air samples fram a large number of Scandinavian Airline
Systen (sAs) flights under various conditions. Besides concentrations of re-
spirable suspended particles (Rsp), nicotine and carbon monoxide, which are used
rature were used to evaluate cabin air quality. No observations of health effects
were made.
SHOOK HARDY & BACON
